newsitem.title: UK: UK retailers forecast steady Q4 sales growth - D&B.
newsitem.headline: UK retailers forecast steady Q4 sales growth - D&B.

text.p: British retailers and wholesalers are expecting steady growth in the fourth quarter as consumer confidence increases, a survey by Dun & Bradstreet showed.
Two-thirds of wholesalers and about 60 percent of retail and service sector businesses expect an increase in new orders over the next few months.
All three sectors forecast an increase in net sales, net profits and inventories and also increased exports.
"Business expectations are continuing to improve, which is good news for the UK economy, but it must be taken in context," said Philip Mellor, senior analyst at D&B.

"The improvement is largely due to seasonal factors. It remains to be seen if business confidence will be sustained through the first quarter of 1997 and in the run-up to the general election." UK elections are due by May 1997.
The D&B survey of 1,600 managing directors showed most saw subdued selling prices and low inflationary pressures.

"A positive upside is that expectations for increased selling prices have risen only modestly," Mellor said. "Inflationary pressures will remain subdued, enhancing the prospect that the Chancellor will maintain interest rates at the current rate through the short-term."
The survey showed employers remain cautious about increasing staffing levels.
